<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>There are <em>two</em> records!</p>
<p>The first record indicates Julia's purchase for <code>transaction_id</code> of <code>1</code> and later a sale with <code>transaction_id</code> of <code>2</code>.</p>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A pivotal part of data analysis is to create new columns based on some operation. This tutorial will cover multiple ways to do that.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Modules">Import Modules<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Modules">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">matplotlib</span> <span class="n">inline</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Get-Tips-Dataset">Get Tips Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Get-Tips-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's get the <code>tips</code> dataset from the Python <a href='https://seaborn.pydata.org/'>`seaborn` visualization library</a> and assign it to the DataFrame <code>df_tips</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load_dataset</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'tips'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Each row represents a unique meal at a restaurant for a party of people; the dataset contains the following fields:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th>column name</th>
<th>column description </th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code>total_bill</code></td>
<td>financial amount of meal in U.S. dollars</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>tip</code></td>
<td>financial amount of the meal's tip in U.S. dollars</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>sex</code></td>
<td>gender of server</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>smoker</code></td>
<td>boolean to represent if server smokes or not</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>day</code></td>
<td>day of week</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>time</code></td>
<td>meal name (Lunch or Dinner)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>size</code></td>
<td>count of people eating meal</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Preview the first 5 rows of <code>df_tips</code> using the pandas series <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.Series.head.html'>`head()` method</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Create-New-Column-Based-on-Mathematical-Operations-of-Column(s)">Create New Column Based on Mathematical Operations of Column(s)<a class="anchor-link" href="#Create-New-Column-Based-on-Mathematical-Operations-of-Column(s)">¶</a></h3>

</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can perform mathematical operations on columns such as addition, division and multiplication.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Addition">Addition<a class="anchor-link" href="#Addition">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's create a new column called <code>total_money_received</code> that's the addition of the <code>total_bill</code> and <code>tip</code> column. This total amount is how much money the restaurant receives for each order.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'total_money_received'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's see a preview of these three columnns.</p>

</div>
</div>

<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'tip'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'total_money_received'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>

</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's create a new column called <code>tip_proportion_of_total_bill</code> that's a calculation of <code>tip</code> values divided by their respective <code>total_bill</code> value.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_proportion_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>

</div>

</div>

<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'tip'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'tip_proportion_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>For aesthetic purposes of the values in the <code>tip_proportion_of_total_bill</code>, I will round all values to four decimal places using the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.round.html'>`round()` method</a> below.</p>

</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_proportion_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_proportion_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">decimals</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Additionally, I want to create a new column called <code>money_received_per_person</code> that's a calculation of <code>total_money_received</code> divided by <code>size</code>. I round values in this new column to two decimal places.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'total_money_received'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">decimals</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

<h4 id="Multiplication">Multiplication<a class="anchor-link" href="#Multiplication">¶</a></h4>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I want to create a new column called <code>tip_percentage_of_total_bill</code> that simply takes our column called <code>tip_proportion_of_total_bill</code> and multiplies the value by 100. I round values in this new column to two decimal places.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_percentage_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_proportion_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span>
<span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_percentage_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'tip_percentage_of_total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">decimals</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">

<h3 id="Create-New-Column-Based-on-Mapping-of-Current-Values-to-New-Values">Create New Column Based on Mapping of Current Values to New Values<a class="anchor-link" href="#Create-New-Column-Based-on-Mapping-of-Current-Values-to-New-Values">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In our <code>day</code> column, we see the following unique values printed out below using the pandas series <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.Series.unique.html'>`unique` method</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unique</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[13]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>[Sun, Sat, Thur, Fri]
Categories (4, object): [Sun, Sat, Thur, Fri]</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I don't like how the days are shortened names. The name <code>Sun</code> can be mapped to a longer and more colloquial name of <code>Sunday</code>.</p>
<p>In pandas, we can use the series <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.Series.map.html'>`map()` method</a> to map our current values, the shortened 
day names, to longer more colloquial names of days, our new values that we'll create in a new column called <code>day_long_name</code>.</p>
<p>Below is a Python dictionary that assigns the short day names as keys and the longer names to their respective values.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">short_day_name_to_long_name</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'Sun'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Sunday'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Sat'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Saturday'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Thur'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Thursday'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Fri'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Friday'</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's assign the <code>map()</code> method to the <code>day</code> column and set the argument <code>arg</code> equal to our <code>short_day_name_to_long_name</code> dictionary. We'll set this equal to be the values in a new column assigned to <code>day_long_name</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day_long_name'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">arg</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">short_day_name_to_long_name</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's preview a few random rows of <code>day</code> and <code>day_long_name</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>

<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>

<h3 id="Create-New-Column-Based-on-Conditions-Across-Various-Columns">Create New Column Based on Conditions Across Various Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#Create-New-Column-Based-on-Conditions-Across-Various-Columns">¶</a></h3>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>If I were the owner of this restaurant, I'd want to learn more about the context of large groups who ordered a large dollar amount of food. To learn more about this category, I want to create a new column in our DataFrame with these characteristics.</p>
<p>First, let's view the distribution of the column <code>money_received_per_person</code>.</p>

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_context</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'talk'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">figure</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">boxplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'green'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Distribution of Money Received Per Person Values"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">1.015</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"money received per person [$]"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">labelpad</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can see the median is roughly at 8.50 U.S. dollars.</p>
<p>Below, I assign variables for the 75th and 25th percentile of the <code>money_received_per_person</code> column that we'll use in our analysis to help create the category of big spenders per person.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">large_amt_paid_per_person</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">quantile</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">q</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.75</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">large_amt_paid_per_person</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[17]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>10.71</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">small_amt_paid_per_person</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">quantile</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">q</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.25</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">small_amt_paid_per_person</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[18]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>6.75</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Below, I assign a variable <code>conditions</code> to be a list of conditions that characterize people served at our restaurant by the columns <code>money_received_per_person</code> and <code>size</code>. In our first index of the variable <code>conditions</code>, that condition is met if <code>money_received_per_person</code> is greater than <code>large_amt_paid_per_person</code> and <code>size</code> is greater than or equal to 3.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">conditions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="n">large_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">>=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="n">large_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">left</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">small_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">right</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">large_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">>=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">left</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">small_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">right</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">large_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="n">small_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">>=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'money_received_per_person'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="n">small_amt_paid_per_person</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>There's a variable called <code>choices</code> that's a list of text strings that classify this category of people that meet this condition. In the example described above, I want to classify that group of people that spend a lot of money per person and are large groups as <code>big spenders & large group</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">choices</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'big spenders & large group'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'big spenders & small group'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
           <span class="s1">'medium spenders & large group'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'medium spenders & small group'</span><span class="p">,</span>
           <span class="s1">'small spenders & large group'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'small spenders & small group'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The numpy <code>select()</code> method returns an array drawn from elements in a choicelist. We can use our conditions above and are outcome choices to classify those groups of people based on money spent per person and group size.</p>
<p>In the <code>select()</code> method below, I set the argument <code>condlist</code> to be our <code>conditions</code> and the argument <code>choicelist</code> to be our <code>choices</code>.  I created the variables <code>conditions</code> and <code>choices</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'party_category'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">select</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">condlist</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">conditions</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">choicelist</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">choices</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>For the new column created <code>party_category</code>, I apply the <code>value_counts()</code> method to see a count of each of the unique values in the column.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'party_category'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[22]:</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A <strong>group by</strong> is a process that tyipcally involves splitting the data into groups based on some criteria, applying a function to each group independently, and then combining the outputted results.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Modules">Import Modules<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Modules">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [89]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Get-Tips-Dataset">Get Tips Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Get-Tips-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's get the <code>tips</code> dataset from the <code>seaborn</code> library and assign it to the DataFrame <code>df_tips</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [90]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load_dataset</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'tips'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Each row represents a unique meal at a restaurant for a party of people; the dataset contains the following fields:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th>column name</th>
<th>column description </th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code>total_bill</code></td>
<td>financial amount of meal in U.S. dollars</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>tip</code></td>
<td>financial amount of the meal's tip in U.S. dollars</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>sex</code></td>
<td>gender of server</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>smoker</code></td>
<td>boolean to represent if server smokes or not</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>day</code></td>
<td>day of week</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>time</code></td>
<td>meal name (Lunch or Dinner)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>size</code></td>
<td>count of people eating meal</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Preview the first 5 rows of <code>df_tips</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [91]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[91]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Implement-Group-bys-with-Tips-Dataset">Implement Group bys with Tips Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Implement-Group-bys-with-Tips-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-a-Single-Aggregate-Method-on-a-Column">Group by of a Single Column and Apply a Single Aggregate Method on a Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-a-Single-Aggregate-Method-on-a-Column">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The simplest example of a <code>groupby()</code> operation is to compute the size of groups in a single column. By size, the calculation is a count of unique occurences of values in a single column. Here is the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.core.groupby.GroupBy.size.html'>official documentation</a> for this operation.</p>
<p>This is the same operation as utilizing the <code>value_counts()</code> method in pandas.</p>
<p>Below, for the <code>df_tips</code> DataFrame, I call the <code>groupby()</code> method, pass in the <code>sex</code> column, and then chain the <code>size()</code> method.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [92]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">size</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[92]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>sex
Male      157
Female     87
dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To interpret the output above, 157 meals were served by males and 87 meals were served by females.</p>
<p>A note, if there are any <code>NaN</code> or <code>NaT</code> values in the grouped column that would appear in the index, those are automatically excluded in your output (<a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.22/groupby.html#na-and-nat-group-handling'>reference here</a>).</p>
<p>In pandas, we can also group by one columm and then perform an aggregate method on a different column.</p>
<p>For example, in our dataset, I want to group by the <code>sex</code> column and then across the <code>total_bill</code> column, find the mean bill size. To do this in pandas, given our <code>df_tips</code> DataFrame, apply the <code>groupby()</code> method and pass in the <code>sex</code> column (that'll be our index), and then reference our <code>['total_bill']</code> column (that'll be our returned column) and chain the <code>mean()</code> method.</p>
<p>Meals served by males had a mean bill size of 20.74 while meals served by females had a mean bill size of 18.06.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [93]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[93]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>sex
Male      20.744076
Female    18.056897
Name: total_bill, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can verify the output above with a query. We get the same result that meals served by males had a mean bill size of 20.74</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [94]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">query</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"sex=='Male'"</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[94]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>20.744076433121034</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Another interesting tidbit with the <code>groupby()</code> method is the ability to group by a single column, and call an aggregate method that will apply to all other numeric columns in the DataFrame.</p>
<p>For example, if I group by the <code>sex</code> column and call the <code>mean()</code> method, the mean is calculated for the three other numeric columns in <code>df_tips</code> which are <code>total_bill</code>, <code>tip</code>, and <code>size</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [95]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Aggregate-Methods">Aggregate Methods<a class="anchor-link" href="#Aggregate-Methods">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Other aggregate methods you could perform with a <code>groupby()</code> method in pandas are:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th>method</th>
<th>description </th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code>sum()</code></td>
<td>summation </td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>mean()</code></td>
<td>average</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>count()</code></td>
<td>count of all values</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>size()</code></td>
<td>count of non-null values</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>max()</code></td>
<td>maximum value</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>min()</code></td>
<td>minimum value</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>std()</code></td>
<td>standard deviation</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>median()</code></td>
<td>median</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To illustrate the difference between the <code>size()</code> and <code>count()</code> methods, I included this simple example below.</p>
<p>The DataFrame below of <code>df_rides</code> includes Dan and Jamie's ride data.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [96]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'person'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Dan'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Dan'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Jamie'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Jamie'</span><span class="p">],</span> 
        <span class="s1">'ride_duration_minutes'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">NaN</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">8</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">]}</span>
<span class="n">df_rides</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_rides</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[96]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

    </tr>

</div>

</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>For one of Dan's rides, the <code>ride_duration_minutes</code> value is null. However, if we apply the <code>size</code> method, we'll still see a count of <code>2</code> rides for Dan. We are 100% sure he took 2 rides but there's only a small issue in our dataset in which the the exact duration of one ride wasn't recorded.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [97]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_rides</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'person'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'ride_duration_minutes'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">size</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[97]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>person
Dan      2
Jamie    2
Name: ride_duration_minutes, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Upon applying the <code>count()</code> method, we only see a count of <code>1</code> for Dan because that's the number of non-null values in the <code>ride_duration_minutes</code> field that belongs to him.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [98]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_rides</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'person'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'ride_duration_minutes'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">count</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[98]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>person
Dan      1
Jamie    2
Name: ride_duration_minutes, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-the-describe()-Method-on-a-Single-Column">Group by of a Single Column and Apply the <code>describe()</code> Method on a Single Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-the-describe()-Method-on-a-Single-Column">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>With grouping of a single column, you can also apply the <code>describe()</code> method to a numerical column. Below, I group by the <code>sex</code> column, reference the <code>total_bill</code> column and apply the <code>describe()</code> method on its values. The <code>describe</code> method outputs many descriptive statistics. Learn more about the <code>describe()</code> method on the official <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.describe.html'>documentation page</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [99]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">describe</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-a-Lambda-Expression-on-a-Single-Column">Group by of a Single Column and Apply a Lambda Expression on a Single Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-a-Lambda-Expression-on-a-Single-Column">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Most examples in this tutorial involve using simple aggregate methods like calculating the mean, sum or a count. However, with group bys, we have flexibility to apply custom lambda functions.</p>
<p>You can learn more about lambda expressions from the <a href='https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/controlflow.html#lambda-expressions'>Python 3 documentation</a> and about using instance methods in group bys from the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.22/groupby.html#dispatching-to-instance-methods'>official pandas documentation</a>.</p>
<p>Below, I group by the <code>sex</code> column and apply a lambda expression to the <code>total_bill</code> column. The expression is to find the range of <code>total_bill</code> values. The range is the maximum value subtracted by the minimum value. I also rename the single column returned on output so it's understandable.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [100]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">bill</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">bill</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">max</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">bill</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">min</span><span class="p">()})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"range_total_bill"</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[100]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In this dataset, males had a bigger range of <code>total_bill</code> values.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Group-by-of-Multiple-Columns-and-Apply-a-Single-Aggregate-Method-on-a-Column">Group by of Multiple Columns and Apply a Single Aggregate Method on a Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Group-by-of-Multiple-Columns-and-Apply-a-Single-Aggregate-Method-on-a-Column">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can group by multiple columns too. For example, I want to know the count of meals served by people's gender for each day of the week. So, call the <code>groupby()</code> method and set the <code>by</code> argument to a list of the columns we want to group by.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [101]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">size</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[101]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>sex     day 
Male    Thur    30
        Fri     10
        Sat     59
        Sun     58
Female  Thur    32
        Fri      9
        Sat     28
        Sun     18
dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can also group by multiple columns and apply an aggregate method on a different column. Below I group by people's gender and day of the week and find the total sum of those groups' bills.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [102]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">])[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[102]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>sex     day 
Male    Thur     561.44
        Fri      198.57
        Sat     1227.35
        Sun     1269.46
Female  Thur     534.89
        Fri      127.31
        Sat      551.05
        Sun      357.70
Name: total_bill, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-Multiple-Aggregate-Methods-on-a-Column">Group by of a Single Column and Apply Multiple Aggregate Methods on a Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Group-by-of-a-Single-Column-and-Apply-Multiple-Aggregate-Methods-on-a-Column">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The <code>agg()</code> method allows us to specify multiple functions to apply to each column. Below, I group by the <code>sex</code> column and then we'll apply multiple aggregate methods to the <code>total_bill</code> column. Inside the <code>agg()</code> method, I pass a dictionary and specify <code>total_bill</code> as the key and a list of aggregate methods as the value.</p>
<p>You can pass various types of syntax inside the argument for the <code>agg()</code> method. I chose a dictionary because that syntax will be helpful when we want to apply aggregate methods to multiple columns later on in this tutorial.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [103]:</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Below, I use the <code>agg()</code> method to apply two different aggregate methods to two different columns. I group by the <code>sex</code> column and for the <code>total_bill</code> column, apply the <code>max</code> method, and for the <code>tip</code> column, apply the <code>min</code> method.</p>

</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">

<h4 id="Group-by-of-Multiple-Columns-and-Apply-a-Groupwise-Calculation-on-Multiple-Columns">Group by of Multiple Columns and Apply a Groupwise Calculation on Multiple Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#Group-by-of-Multiple-Columns-and-Apply-a-Groupwise-Calculation-on-Multiple-Columns">¶</a></h4>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In restaurants, common math by guests is to calculate the tip for the waiter/waittress. My mom thinks 20% tip is customary. So, if the bill was 10, you should tip 2 and pay 12 in total. I'm curious what the tip percentages are based on the gender of servers, meal and day of the week. We can perform that calculation with a <code>groupby()</code> and the <code>pipe()</code> method.</p>
<p>The <code>pipe()</code> method allows us to call functions in a <em>chain</em>. So as the <code>groupby()</code> method is called, at the same time, another function is being called to perform data manipulations. You can learn more about <code>pipe()</code> from the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.22/groupby.html#piping-function-calls'>official documentation</a>.</p>
<p>To perform this calculation, we need to group by <code>sex</code>, <code>time</code> and <code>day</code>, then call our <code>pipe()</code> method and calculate the <code>tip</code> divided by <code>total_bill</code> multiplied by <code>100</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [107]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'time'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pipe</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">group</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">group</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tip</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">group</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">total_bill</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In pandas, for a column in a DataFrame, we can use the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.Series.value_counts.html'>`value_counts()` method</a> to easily count the unique occurences of values.</p>
<p>There's additional interesting analyis we can do with <code>value_counts()</code> too. We'll try them out using the titanic dataset.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Module">Import Module<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Module">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [27]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Get-Titanic-Dataset">Get Titanic Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Get-Titanic-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We'll use the <em>titanic</em> dataset included in the seaborn library.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [28]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load_dataset</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'titanic'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Below is a preview of the first few rows of the dataset.</p>
<p>Each row includes details of a person who boarded the famous Titanic cruise ship.</p>
<p>In this tutorial, we're just going to utilize the <code>sex</code> and <code>fare</code> columns. The <code>sex</code> column classifies the person's gender as male or female. The <code>fare</code> column indicates the dollar amount each person paid to board the Titanic.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [29]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[29]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Fun-with-value_counts()">Fun with <code>value_counts()</code><a class="anchor-link" href="#Fun-with-value_counts()">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Here is the simple use of <code>value_counts()</code> we call on the <code>sex</code> column that returns us the count of occurences of each of the unique values in this column.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[30]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>male      577
female    314
Name: sex, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now, we want to do the same operation, but this time sort our outputted values in the <code>sex</code> column, male and female, so that values that start with the letter <em>a</em> appear at the top and values that start with letter <em>z</em> appear at the bottom. This is considered ascending order.</p>
<p><em>f</em> is before <em>m</em> in the alphabet so we see female before male.</p>
<p>In our <code>value_counts</code> method, we'll set the argument <code>ascending</code> to <code>True</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [31]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ascending</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[31]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>female    314
male      577
Name: sex, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Often times, we want to know what percentage of the whole is for each value that appears in the column. For example, if we took the two counts above, 577 and 314 and we sum them up, we'd get 891. So, what percentage of people on the titanic were male. The calculation is 577/891 x 100 = 64.75%.</p>
<p>To calculate this in pandas with the <code>value_counts()</code> method, set the argument <code>normalize</code> to <code>True</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [32]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">normalize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[32]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>male      0.647587
female    0.352413
Name: sex, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Before we try a new <code>value_counts()</code> argument, let's take a look at some basic descriptive statistics of the <code>fare</code> column. To accomplish this, we'll call the <code>describe()</code> method on the column.</p>
<p>There's 891 values of fare data, a mean of 32 and a standard deviation of 49 which indicates a fairly wide spread of data.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [33]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fare'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">describe</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[33]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>count    891.000000
mean      32.204208
std       49.693429
min        0.000000
25%        7.910400
50%       14.454200
75%       31.000000
max      512.329200
Name: fare, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Another interesting feature of the <code>value_counts()</code> method is that it can be used to bin continuous data into discrete intervals. We set the argument <code>bins</code> to an integer representing the number of bins to create.</p>
<p>For each bin, the range of fare amounts in dollar values is the same. One contains fares from 73.19 to 146.38 which is a range of 73.19. Another bin contains fares from 146.38 to 73.19 which is also a range of 73.19. See how the ranges are same! However, inside each range of fare values can contain a different count of the number of tickets bought by passengers of the Titanic.</p>
<p>We can see most people paid under 73.19 for their ticket.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [34]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'fare'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">bins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">7</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[34]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>(-0.513, 73.19]       789
(73.19, 146.38]        71
(146.38, 219.57]       15
(219.57, 292.76]       13
(439.139, 512.329]      3
(365.949, 439.139]      0
(292.76, 365.949]       0
Name: fare, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In pandas, we can "unpivot" a DataFrame - turn it from a <em>wide</em> format - many columns - to a <em>long</em> format - few columns but many rows. We can accomplish this with the pandas <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.23.4/generated/pandas.melt.html'>`melt()`</a> method. This can be helpful for further analysis of our new unpivoted DataFrame.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Module">Import Module<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Module">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Example:-Pivot-Tesla-Car-Acceleration-Details">Example: Pivot Tesla Car Acceleration Details<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example:-Pivot-Tesla-Car-Acceleration-Details">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Here is fictional acceleration tests for three popular Tesla car models. In order to verify acceleration of the cars, I figured a third-party may make three <em>runs</em> to test the three models alongside one another.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">s</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Tesla Model S P100D'</span>
<span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Tesla Model X P100D'</span>
<span class="n">three</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Tesla Model 3 AWD Dual Motor'</span>

<span class="n">s_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">s</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.51</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.54</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">x_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.92</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.91</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.93</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">three_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">three</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.33</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.31</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.35</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">s_data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x_data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">three_data</span><span class="p">]</span> 
<span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'car_model'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Sept 1 9am'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Sept 1 10am'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Sept 1 11am'</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">df</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[21]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

      <th></th>

      <th>Sept 1 10am</th>
      <th>Sept 1 11am</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>

    <tr>
