      <td>2.54</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>1</th>
      <td>Tesla Model X P100D</td>
      <td>2.92</td>
      <td>2.91</td>
      <td>2.93</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>2</th>
      <td>Tesla Model 3 AWD Dual Motor</td>
      <td>3.33</td>
      <td>3.31</td>
      <td>3.35</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Notice how this DataFrame features four columns, one for the car model name, and three for acceleration <em>runs</em> of a car. If they were to continue with this trend of data collection and do far more <em>runs</em>, this dataset would have lots of columns - perhaps making it daunting to visualize and analyze.</p>
<p>I want to "unpivot" this data from a wide format to a long format using the pandas <code>melt()</code> method.</p>
<p>On the <code>df</code> DataFrame, we'll call the <code>melt()</code> method and set the following arguments:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>id_vars</code> to <code>['car_model']</code> since each row from <code>df</code> is identified by the car model name</li>
<li><code>var_name</code> to <code>'date'</code> since this new column needs a name</li>
<li><code>value_name</code> to <code>'0-60mph_in_seconds'</code> since this new column needs a name</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_unpivoted</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">melt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">id_vars</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'car_model'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">var_name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'date'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value_name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'0-60mph_in_seconds'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df_unpivoted</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[22]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>
<style scoped>

        vertical-align: middle;

    <tr>

    </tr>
    <tr>

      <td>3.31</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>6</th>

      <td>2.54</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>7</th>

      <td>Sept 1 11am</td>
      <td>2.93</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <th>8</th>
      <td>Tesla Model 3 AWD Dual Motor</td>
      <td>Sept 1 11am</td>
      <td>3.35</td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>After this "unpivot", we can easily calculate the minimum (essentially the fastest) 0-60 time that we'd publish in a final report. To do so, we take our <code>df_unpivoted</code> DataFrame, group by the <code>car_model</code> column, and find the minimum value in the <code>0-60mph_in_seconds</code> column.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_unpivoted</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'car_model'</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'0-60mph_in_seconds'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">min</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In pandas, we can pivot our DataFrame without applying an aggregate operation. This pivot is helpful to see our data in a different way - often turning a format with many rows that would require scrolling into a new format with fewer rows but perhaps more columns.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Module">Import Module<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Module">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [48]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Example:-Pivot-Tesla-Car-Acceleration-Details">Example: Pivot Tesla Car Acceleration Details<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example:-Pivot-Tesla-Car-Acceleration-Details">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Here is fictional acceleration tests for three popular Tesla car models. In order to verify acceleration of the cars, I figured a third-party may make three <em>runs</em> to test the three models alongside one another.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [49]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">s</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Tesla Model S P100D'</span>
<span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Tesla Model X P100D'</span>
<span class="n">three</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Tesla Model 3 AWD Dual Motor'</span>

<span class="n">models</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">s</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">three</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span>
<span class="n">dates</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Sept 1 9am'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Sept 1 10am'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Sept 1 11am'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span>
<span class="n">acceleration_times</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mf">2.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.92</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.33</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.51</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.91</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.31</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.51</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">2.92</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">3.3</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'car_model'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">models</span><span class="p">,</span> 
        <span class="s1">'date'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">dates</span><span class="p">,</span> 
        <span class="s1">'0-60mph_in_seconds'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">acceleration_times</span><span class="p">}</span> 
<span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I want to pivot this data so each row is a unique car model, the columns are dates and the values in the table are the acceleration speeds.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [50]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pivot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'car_model'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'date'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">values</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'0-60mph_in_seconds'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>Pivot tables</strong> allow us to perform group-bys on columns and specify aggregate metrics for columns too. This data analysis technique is very popular in GUI spreadsheet applications and also works well in Python using the pandas package and the DataFrame <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.pivot_table.html'>pivot_table() method</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Modules">Import Modules<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Modules">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Example-1:-Pivot-Tables-with-Flights-Dataset">Example 1: Pivot Tables with Flights Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example-1:-Pivot-Tables-with-Flights-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Get-Data">Get Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Get-Data">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's get the <code>flights</code> dataset included in the <code>seaborn</code> library and assign it to the DataFrame <code>df_flights</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [26]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_flights</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load_dataset</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'flights'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Preview the first few rows of <code>df_flights</code>.</p>
<p>Each row represents a month's flight history details. The <code>passengers</code> column represents that total number of passengers that flew that month.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [27]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_flights</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<h4 id="Implement-Pivot-Tables">Implement Pivot Tables<a class="anchor-link" href="#Implement-Pivot-Tables">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I want to know the sum of passengers that flew on planes for each year. So, from pandas, we'll call the <code>pivot_table()</code> method and set the following arguments:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>data</code> to be our DataFrame <code>df_flights</code></li>
<li><code>index</code> to be <code>'year'</code> since that's the column from <code>df_flights</code> that we want to appear as a unique value in each row</li>
<li><code>values</code> as <code>'passengers'</code> since that's the column we want to apply some aggregate operation on</li>
<li><code>aggfunc</code> to <code>'sum'</code> since we want to sum (aka total) up all values in <code>passengers</code> that belong to a unique year</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [28]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pivot_table</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_flights</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">values</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'passengers'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">aggfunc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sum'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[28]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>year
1949    1520

1953    2700

1955    3408

Name: passengers, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can see above that every year, the total number of passengers that flew increased each year. However, this pivot table is poorly documented. There's no column name or label for the values on the right. To fix this, we'll cast this outputted series to a DataFrame and rename the aggregated column to be clearer.</p>
<p>Use the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.reset_index.html' rel='nofollow'>`reset_index()`</a> method to cast our series to a DataFrame with a new index and then chain the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.rename.html' rel='nofollow'>`rename()`</a> method to rename the <code>'passengers'</code> column to <code>'total_passengers'</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [29]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pivot_table</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_flights</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'year'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">values</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'passengers'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">aggfunc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sum'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'passengers'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'total_passengers'</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>

<p>For each day and meal type, I'm curious to find the median bill amount. So, from pandas, we'll call the <code>pivot_table()</code> method and set the following arguments:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>data</code> to be our DataFrame <code>df_tips</code></li>
<li><code>index</code> to be <code>['day', 'time']</code> since we want to aggregate by both of those columns so each row represents a unique type of meal for a day </li>
<li><code>values</code> as <code>'total_bill'</code> since that's the column we want to apply some aggregate operation on</li>
<li><code>aggfunc</code> to <code>'median'</code> since we want to find the median value in our <code>total_bill</code> column for each day's meal type in our dataset</li>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A <strong>crosstab</strong> computes aggregated metrics among two or more columns in a dataset that contains categorical values.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Modules">Import Modules<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Modules">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [122]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">seaborn</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sns</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Get-Tips-Dataset">Get Tips Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Get-Tips-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's get the <code>tips</code> dataset from the <code>seaborn</code> library and assign it to the DataFrame <code>df_tips</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [123]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load_dataset</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'tips'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Each row represents a unique meal at a restaurant for a party of people; the dataset contains the following fields:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th>column name</th>
<th>column description </th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code>total_bill</code></td>
<td>financial amount of meal in U.S. dollars</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>tip</code></td>
<td>financial amount of the meal's tip in U.S. dollars</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>sex</code></td>
<td>gender of server</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>smoker</code></td>
<td>boolean to represent if server smokes or not</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>day</code></td>
<td>day of week</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>time</code></td>
<td>meal name (Lunch or Dinner)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code>size</code></td>
<td>count of people eating meal</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Preview the first 5 rows of <code>df_tips</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [124]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[124]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Implement-Crosstabs-with-Tips-Dataset">Implement Crosstabs with Tips Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Implement-Crosstabs-with-Tips-Dataset">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Grouping-By-a-Single-Field-for-the-Index-and-Column">Grouping By a Single Field for the Index and Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Grouping-By-a-Single-Field-for-the-Index-and-Column">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's compute a simple crosstab across the <code>day</code> and <code>sex</code> column. We want our returned index to be the unique values from <code>day</code> and our returned columns to be the unique values from <code>sex</code>. By default in pandas, the <code>crosstab()</code> computes an aggregated metric of a count (aka frequency).</p>
<p>So, each of the values inside our table represent a count across the index and column. For example, males served 30 unique groups across all Thursdays in our dataset.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [125]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[125]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">

      <th>sex</th>
      <th>Male</th>
      <th>Female</th>
    </tr>
    <tr>

    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>

</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>One issue with this crosstab output is the column names are nonsensical. Just saying <code>Male</code> or <code>Female</code> isn't very specific. They should be renamed to be clearer. We can use the <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/generated/pandas.DataFrame.rename.html'>rename()</a> method and set the argument <code>columns</code> to be a dictionary in which the keys are the current column names and the values are the respective new names to set.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [126]:</div>

<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">colnames</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'gender'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">margins</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">margins_name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"proportion_meals_served"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">normalize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'columns'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"Male"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"proportion_meals_served_by_males"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"Female"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"proportion_meals_served_by_females"</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Given two categorical columns, the <code>crosstab()</code> method can additionally utilize a column with numerical values to perform an aggregate operation. That sentence may sound daunting - so let's walk through it with a simple example.</p>
<p>We know there exists <code>total_bill</code> values in our datasets for males that served meals on Thursday. Below, I preview the first few <code>total_bill</code> values that meet this criteria.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [134]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">query</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"sex=='Male' and day=='Thur'"</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[134]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>77    27.20
78    22.76
79    17.29
80    19.44
81    16.66
Name: total_bill, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We may want to know the average bill size that meet the criteria above. So, given that series, we can calculate the mean and we arrive at a result of 18.71.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [135]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">query</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"sex=='Male' and day=='Thur'"</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[135]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>18.714666666666666</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now, we can perform this same operation using the <code>crosstab()</code> method. Same as before, we want our returned index to be the unique values from <code>day</code> and our returned columns to be the unique values from <code>sex</code>. Additionally, we want the values inside the table to be from our <code>total_bill</code> column so we'll set the argument <code>values</code> to be <code>df_tips['total_bill']</code>. We also want to calculate the mean total bill for each combination of a day and gender so we'll set the <code>aggfunc</code> argument to <code>'mean'</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [136]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">values</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'total_bill'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">colnames</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'gender'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">aggfunc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'mean'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"Male"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"mean_bill_size_meals_served_by_males"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"Female"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"mean_bill_size_meals_served_by_females"</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[136]:</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This crosstab calculation outputted the same 18.71 value as expected!</p>
<p>We can pass in many other aggregate methods to the <code>aggfunc</code> method too such as mean and standard deviation.</p>
<p>You can learn more about details of using <code>crosstab()</code> from the official pandas <a href='https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.22/generated/pandas.crosstab.html'>documentation page</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Grouping-By-Multiple-Fields-for-the-Index-and/or-Columns">Grouping By Multiple Fields for the Index and/or Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#Grouping-By-Multiple-Fields-for-the-Index-and/or-Columns">¶</a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can also use the <code>crosstabs()</code> method to group by multiple pandas columns for the <code>index</code> or <code>columns</code> arguments.</p>
<p>For example, we can find out for days of the week, for each gender, what was the count of meals they served for lunch or dinner. In pandas We want our returned index to be the unique values from <code>day</code> and our returned columns to be the unique values from all combinations of the <code>sex</code> (gender) and <code>time</code> (meal time) columns.</p>
<p>To interpret a value from our table below, across all Thursdays in our dataset, females served 31 lunch meals.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [137]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'time'</span><span class="p">]],</span> <span class="n">colnames</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'gender'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'meal'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"Lunch"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"count_lunch_meals_served"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"Dinner"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"count_dinner_meals_served"</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[137]:</div>

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can verify the logic in a value with a separate query. I'm curious to see the count of meals on Thursday served by females during lunch time. Our result on this query is 31 which matches the value in the crosstab above!</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [138]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">query</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"day=='Thur' and sex=='Female' and time=='Lunch'"</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[138]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>If you're familiar with the <code>groupby()</code> method in pandas, the code below performs a similar operation to the crosstab above, but the output format is a little different.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [139]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">])[</span><span class="s1">'time'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">count</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can also group by multiple pandas columns in the <code>index</code> argument of the <code>crosstabs()</code> method.</p>
<p>Below is a fairly complex operation. The code below helps us find out for every combination of day of the week, gender and meal type what was the count of meals served for the various group sizes (ex - party of two people versus party of three).</p>
<p>In our output, the index includes unique values from the <code>day</code> and <code>sex</code> fields while columns include unique values from the <code>time</code> and <code>size</code> fields.</p>
<p>To interpret a value from our table below, across all Thursdays in our dataset, males 24 lunch meals that contained a group of 2 people.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [140]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">crosstab</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'day'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sex'</span><span class="p">]],</span> <span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'time'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">df_tips</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">]],</span> <span class="n">colnames</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'meal'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'party_people_size'</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"Lunch"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"count_lunch_meals_served"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"Dinner"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">"count_dinner_meals_served"</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>

<p>While the above output is daunting to read with all the cells, there's a cool trick in Seaborn to make your DataFrame output appear as a heatmap. </div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="What-is-Categorical-Data">What is Categorical Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#What-is-Categorical-Data">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Categorical data has a limited number of values to choose from for a field of data. Some examples of fields and values are:</p>
<table>
<thead><tr>
<th>Field</th>
<th>Potential Values</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Blood type</td>
<td>O negative, O positive, A negative, B negative</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Customer responses on satisfaction of a product</td>
<td>happy, content, sad</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Eye color</td>
<td>green, blue, brown</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>There are two common types of categorical data: nominal and ordinal.</p>
<p>Nominal categorical data has values with no inherent order such as the eye color example above.</p>
<p>Ordinal categorical data contains values with an intended order. One example is the customer responses above. There's an inherent order with the values - happy is a more positive measurement than content. In my list of potential values, I ordered the values from responses that deem the product most-likeable to least-likeable.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Categorical-Data-in-Pandas">Categorical Data in Pandas<a class="anchor-link" href="#Categorical-Data-in-Pandas">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Generally, the pandas data type of categorical columns is similar to simply strings of text or numerical values. However, with using ordinal categorical data types, there's a few small differences that would affect my typical workflow. Those differences in pandas are sorting as well as calculuating the minimum and maximum values in a column.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Import-Modules">Import Modules<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Modules">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Create-Survey-Responses-Data">Create Survey Responses Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Create-Survey-Responses-Data">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Create a Python list of survey responses that are either <code>happy</code>, <code>content</code>, or <code>sad</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">responses</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"happy"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"happy"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"content"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"content"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"content"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"content"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"happy"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"content"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Create a pandas categorical data structure of these responses; set the <code>ordered</code> argument to <code>True</code> so that order is declared by the <code>categories</code> argument which is the rank of responses in the order of <code>happy</code>, <code>content</code>, or <code>sad</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">survey_responses</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Categorical</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">responses</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">categories</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"happy"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"content"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"sad"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">ordered</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">

<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">type</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">survey_responses</span><span class="p">)</span>

<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

</div>

</div>

<li><code>top</code> shows the highest-occuring categorical value</li>
<li><code>freq</code> shows the frequency/count of the highest-occuring categorical value</li>
